turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: So that, any --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: adjoining apartment, but --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: If this is so --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You can't hear the conversation.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: If this is so, the sound waves are coming through into this room so that they didn't have to -- in order to reach this microphone and amplify it, it would not -- I mean, we can -- there's no evidence to this effect, but it's -- it's obvious that when you got a microphone with a device like this that you could pick it up inside the --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, what I'm trying to get is was there evidence that all they needed to do was to touch that point against the wall and this would have permitted amplification?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: There is no -- there is no testimony to that effect.
I say it can be -- can be drawn from the evidence which is in there.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You could have say that -- you could have said that to the extent to which amplification is made for the -- the sounds are more distinguished and one hears it from across house to house or, across apartment to apartment.
At least, clearly you would say that's outside the scope of all the people.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That's right.
I -- I would say that this was merely hearing more carefully.

I mean, if -- if they got a man -- if -- if they had a man with unusually acute hearing that they took along with them to listen because they couldn't hear, this would be a similar -- a similar thing.
This is a device which enable the -- I -- I want to say that I find this device not entirely satisfactory to amplify sounds --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Have you tried it?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: I have tried it.
I have the detective from the police department bring one up to my office and I tried it in the office.
I couldn't tell --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, they're government walls though, aren't they?
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, I tried it underneath the doors.
I couldn't tell whether Mr. Spritzer was talking to the Solicitor General or his wife.
I just [Laughter] couldn't tell it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You seem to have a kind of fun with this instrument.
[Laughs]

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Can you turn up the power like you would with a little radio?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: This one has a low and a high power.
The one I had was a little different.
It had a knob on it.
It didn't -- it didn't make it any better.
I think that it would be --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, how -- how far did you insert it in Mr. Spritzer's wall?
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, I stuck it under the door because the -- our baseboards weren't up enough.
Maybe -- I don't know that it was a bad test and there's no evidence.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You probably didn't get it again in the heating ducts.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Mr. Justice, this isn't -- is a -- is an exhibit in the case and, in all seriousness, I think that this exhibit should be examined by the individual -- any members of the court that are interested in it because I think that this case should not be decided on some theory that we have here an infernal instrument such as are well describes which is going to enable people to penetrate into other people's privacy beyond a certain extent, and I think you ought to know the particular device which we have here.
And, as I say it's an exhibit --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, what's the purpose of the spike if it isn't to penetrate?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: It is.
It's to -- it's to increase the efficiency of this microphone.
It's to get to something and to conduct the sound from it to the microphone.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, the suggestion -- the suggestion of your admonition to the Court or your helpless suggestion to the Court is that we ought not to outlaw cruel things but merely very refined instruments.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, no.

You ought not to change -- what I mean is you ought not to change the law on the theory that there are some superb race that people are going to use to -- to penetrate to the very depths of our houses until that -- until there is such a thing.
I don't know if there is or not.
The references to the -- to the Senate Committee hearings are -- are interesting.
There -- there is testimony on these -- on these gadgets.
People got up and talked about them.
I don't think that proves that -- what they'll do, but there is -- there is testimony of these things in the future.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, one wouldn't be borrowing sublet when assumed that there'll be improvements on these things that their legitimate does, does one?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, there has been.
As far as I know, no one has had any hesitation about using microphones since Goldman's day and, if this is as much as they can do since Goldman, I think we're fairly safe for some time to come.
Now, let's talk about this hitting the -- the heating duct and the -- and the heating system in the apartment becoming a gigantic microphone.
In the first place, the testimony does not establish that it hit the heating duct.
It may have, it may not.
We don't know what it hit.
If the Government's testimony is correct, it didn't go far enough to hit the heating duct.

If it did hit the heating duct and if the heating system became a gigantic microphone, the only things that were heard in the next room were from the room next door where the gambling operations were taking place and, in one case, it was heard partly by ear and partly with this machine in the stairway, in the entryway where people came in downstairs, just as they came in -- in the house.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Anything heard from the second floor?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Yes, well, the gambling premises were on the second floor.
This was on the second floor.
This is called a dwelling house and it is a dwelling house in a sense that it's made for people to live in, but no one was living in it.
It was -- this was used solely as a gambling headquarters at the time of this -- of this operation.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Was there anything in the test -- testimony offered by the Government to the effect that only the conversation in one room could be heard through this?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: No, no.
If in fact --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You think that (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- it's clear that it could be heard in the stairway in the hall where people came in as well as that one room, but that is the extent of the testimony.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: They -- they -- do they contend that it could not be heard in all the rooms of the house?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, there's no evidence one way or the other on that.
I don't know whether it could be heard in the other rooms or not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did the noises come from the room into which or toward which the spike was projected or from the room above?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: From the -- it came to the room directly opposite, the room where the spike was inserted except, as I say, for one instance where a man came in and knocked on the door and the agents could hear him come into the house and could hear him speak.
And in that case, he wasn't in the room and they could hear that one conversation, and that is the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What length of time did the -- did the overheard conversations take place?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, it took place on a series of days.I think there were three or four days.

What would happen is that the agents, and these agents were Internal Revenue agents and the Metropolitan police, would enter this house around noon or little before noon and the defendants in this case would come in around -- I think, early in the afternoon and they would conduct their betting operations for that day's ballgames and the prize fights that night throughout the afternoon into the evening.
And so, the agents would be there eight hours from noon until 8, 10 o'clock.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Was the recordings that were made of the overheard conversation voluminous?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: There were no recordings made.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I mean or recollection, were they voluminous?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: There were -- there were many, yes.
There were -- the -- the testimony in the case shows not four or five bets being placed, but hundreds of bets being placed that were heard.
I mean, they didn't attempt to give them all.
They -- they gave the testimony as 10 or 15 on this day and 10 or 15, but it's quite apparent they heard hundreds of bets being placed.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And the agents relied solely on their memory for what they heard?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: No, they had notes that were made in which --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, were the notes voluminous?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: I -- I don't know.
I really don't know.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Mr. Davis --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) it's your room -- there were persons in the other rooms you have?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Were there persons in the other rooms?
There's no evidence that anyone went anywhere, but this single room that was used as a betting headquarters.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Did it conduct a raid after this?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Yes, on the basis of this -- on the basis of the evidence which was obtained -- on the basis of what was overheard, they got the search warrant and arrest warrant, and they --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Did they find anybody in any other rooms there?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, one of the people they picked up is he left the building.
The other -- another person was in the -- in the gambling room.
No one was in any other room at the time they went in.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Mr. Davis, you referred us to page 68 with reference to testimony of conversations that were overheard before this contrivance was put in the wall?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: No, not before but without the aid of this contrivance.
This, actually, was heard on the 29th and -- and the contrivance had been used in the 22nd, 23rd and 24th as I recall.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was there any effort -- does the evidence show any effort to give before the contrivance was put in the wall?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: The evidence --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Or was it put in -- I just don't understand quite the sequence of events.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: No.
They -- they did go into the -- into the building first, the place where they had permission to go, 410.
They went in without the device, and I think the evidence is that they felt that they could hear something next door.
They didn't have the device.
They went in early in, as I remembered early in April, maybe March, to find out what was going on and they've heard sounds.
They didn't hear any illegal transactions.
They've got no evidence at that time, but it was after they had been in that they then got the electronic device and listened, as I remember it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Davis, I've been wondering if there's nothing in the evidence to show that this spike hit -- hit the heating apparatus or nothing in the evidence to show that they could hear through it, but many part of the building.
Where did -- where did Judge Washington get his --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- his information --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- to the effect that this created or established a giant microphone?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: I am -- I may have misspoken.
I didn't mean there was no evidence.
The defendant's evidence was that this struck and pushed against the microphone and the defendant brought in experts who said you could hear all through the building.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And you say there was no evidence on the part of the Government contrary to that?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: No, Mr. Chief Justice.
I'd say, if the evidence in the part of the Government is to be given credence, it could not have touched the heating duct.
They didn't -- there was no occasion when the Government witnesses were on the stand to testify as to the heating duct.

But, it's impossible with the description of how far it goes into the wall for this spike to have touched the heating duct if the Government's witnesses are to be believed because they said it only went in five and one-eighth inches and it -- that's not far enough to touch the heating duct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What would have it touched if he didn't touch that?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: It could have touched a log, for example, the --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The what?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: A log, a -- a board, a piece of -- a strip in the wall, it could have touched -- I don't know.
Any number of things could be involved.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: We'll recess.
